title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the taxable year beginning in 2006, with the Secretary remitting the payment to taxpayers within 30 days. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident alien individuals are not eligible for this rebate. The Oil Company Accountability Act introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Eligibility for the rebate excludes individuals with income exceeding $120,000, those eligible for a deduction under section 151, estates or trusts, and nonresident alien individuals. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. The Energy Tax Rebate introduced under the Oil Company Accountability Act excludes certain individuals from eligibility. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code will take effect upon enactment of the Act. The Energy Tax Rebate introduced under the Oil Company Accountability Act excludes certain individuals from eligibility. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code will take effect upon enactment of the Act. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, applicable integrated oil companies must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories and decrease cost of goods sold for the last taxable year ending in 2005. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, gross income will be adjusted accordingly. The taxpayer's gross income will be increased by the excess amount if the increases under paragraph (1) exceed the cost of goods sold. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to the product of $18.75 and the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the historic LIFO layer. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as per section 29(d)(5) before its redesignation by the Energy Tax Incentives Act of 2005. Any adjustment required by this section will not be considered a change in accounting method. No additional tax will be imposed under section 6655 for underpayments of estimated tax related to the taxable year described in subsection (a). An applicable integrated oil company, as defined in the Internal Revenue Code, must meet certain production and revenue criteria. This company is subject to penalties for underpayment of estimated tax installments. An applicable integrated oil company, as defined in the Revenue Code of 1986, must have a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 for its last taxable year ending in 2005. All persons treated as a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are considered as one entity for this purpose. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax if certain conditions are met. The Internal Revenue Code has special rules for dual capacity taxpayers, defined as individuals subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States who receive a specific economic benefit. This benefit is not considered a tax if conditions are met. The Internal Revenue Code has special rules for dual capacity taxpayers who are subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States and receive a specific economic benefit. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to income taxes imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from a trade or business within that country or possession. The term 'income tax' refers to taxes imposed by a foreign country on income from a trade or business within that country. Exceptions apply to certain taxpayers and citizens/residents of the foreign country. The term 'income tax' refers to taxes imposed by a foreign country on income from a trade or business within that country. Exceptions apply to certain taxpayers and citizens/residents of the foreign country. The amendments made by this section define a 'large integrated oil company' based on gross receipts and average daily worldwide production of crude oil. Effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes on income from a trade or business within a foreign country, specifically targeting 'large integrated oil companies' based on production of crude oil. Effective after the enactment of this Act, with exceptions for treaty obligations of the United States.
